div.p:
svasti śrī matirai koṇṭa kōpparakēcaripaṉmarkiu yā
ṇṭu 36 Āvatu Avaṉikaṉntaṟpapurattu mahaādevark
ku kaṇṭaṉ neṟiyāṉ tirutta kuḷattiṉ kiīḻ Apōhanaṅ kiṭaṉ
tu Uṭumpōṭiy āmai tavaḻṉtatu Eppērpaṭṭatu Uṇṇilam Oḻiv' iṉṟiya
Akavēriyum puṟavēriyum miīṉapoōṉṉum vaḷaiyiṟ cuṟṟu Eppēṟpaṭṭatum tāṇi
ya koṇṭu Iraṇṭu taḷiyilum Orō noṉntāviḷakku Erippōmāṉōm
Ittaḷi paṭṭuṭaiyōm Eḻuvōm

app.note: G. Vijayavenugopal proposed to interpret poṉṉum as gold and take the previous word mīṉa as a mistake for īḻa (īḻam, Śrī Laṅkān gold). However, I do not think the mention of gold here would make sense. There are a few other possibilities, although none of them are entirely sactifactory: 1) pōṉṉum: "inside this land where the fishes (mīṉ) go (pōṉṉum) / inside this land where the elevation (mīṉ>mī) goes (pōṉṉum)"; 2) poṉṉum as a mistake for poḷḷum (digging): "inside this land where the elevated (mī) path (ṉa > naṭai) was dug (poḷḷum). This second possibility is based on a similar formula found in #7: Ikkuḷattiṉ minaṭai poḷḷak kuḷattile kalluvatākavum. I have translated it as: we have to clear (kalluvatākavum) in the tank (kuḷattilē), in order to dig (poḷḷa) [for] an elevated (mī) road/path (naṭai) of this tank (ikkuḷattiṉ).
Literally: "the inner lake (aka-v-ēri-y-um) and the outer lake (puṟa-v-ēri-y-um)". It probably refers to a type of land, but the details remain unclear. See also #7 which has a similar formula.

div.p: Fortune! Prosperity! This is the year 36 of Kōpparakesarivarman who has taken Madurai; for Mahādeva of Avaṉikaṉtaṟpapuram, Kaṇṭaṉ Neṟiyāṉ, when he improved tirutta [the land which] was lying kiṭaṉta without enjoyment apōhanaṅ under kīḻ [the irrigation] of the tank kuḷattiṉ, ... uncultivated lands (lit. the land where the turtles āmai crawl tavaḻṉtatu and the lizzards uṭumpu run ōṭi), the inner lands uṇṇilam of whatever name eppērpaṭṭatu were exempted oḻiviṉṟiya, the akavēriyum, the puṟavēriyum, the mīṉapoṉṉum and whatever name eppēṟpaṭṭatum inside [this land] vaḷaiyiṟ cuṟṟu, having taken koṇṭu ..., we, the Paṭṭuṭaiyars of this temple, we the Seven eḻuvōm, will burn a perpetual lamp orō nontāviḷakku in both the temples iraṇṭu taḷiyilum.
This edition and translation by Valérie Gillet based on autopsy and photographs (2020).
